reviews.title: Along The Path
text: We walked The Path from Union Station over to the Rod Robbie Bridge it’s an interesting walk through an inside walkway around  the Downtown Toronto area. It connects many of the Sports Complex’s there. Good experience and exercise

reviews.title: Unique
text: We had beautiful weather during our trip, so we just wandered down here for a bit to see it when we also visited Nathan Phillips Square. It seems like a great idea for a city that sees very cold weather, but it was pretty empty down there currently.

reviews.title: Lost in the underground
text: Interesting to see, almost impossible to navigate, obviously GPS not working there, no indoor navigation system eg based on UWB present, insufficient signs to even locate subway stations, only worth to see and go back upstairs….. even locals sometimes don’t know the way :-(

reviews.title: Path to the underground
text: Amazing gem of Toronto, so many hidden restaurants, cafes and place to shop! Beautiful find! It's great to find a way to navigate downtown Toronto without trains or automobiles.

reviews.title: Great in bad weather
text: We were lucky in the fact our hotel had direct link to the Path. It is a great way to go went the weather is either cold ar raining hard. As a visitor it was difficult to navigate at times and we existed in the wrong places at times.

reviews.title: Hard to follow, signs appear and disappear at random
text: This is a great idea but, in reality, it's confusing as hell! It's very hard to follow if you're visiting and aren't used to it, the signs seem to appear and disappear at random points and they're written in a style that don't catch your eye. Also, if you're trying to follow it on a map on your phone good luck, you regularly lose signal when you go below ground.

reviews.title: PATH way a bit tricky
text: Trying to navigate my way through it was a bit of a challenge because even with the Google Maps it did not always put me in the right direction but I realized if you're just going from one end to the other you will probably be okay. The stores close pretty early but I noticed quite a few food courts and places to sit down. There was one section of it that I could smell urine but for the most part it was pretty clean and well lit. I like it because it's conveniently Underground and when it's cold out you don't have to battle the elements.

reviews.title: A great way to get around downtown Toronto
text: The PATH helped us stay out of the cold wet weather in Toronto when we were there. It helped also because our hotel and the locations we were going to was easily navigated to by the PATH system and maps. Nice to be able to go to Scotiabank arena from the hotel without having to go outside. The shops and restaurants were neat to see also.

A tip that we learned is navigate old school with street names and addresses and not with your phone through Apple maps or Google Maps until we were back outside walking on the street.  At least our phones went crazy walking in the PATH system when we were trying to locate an address.

reviews.title: Great for avoiding unpleasant weather and traffic
text: When downtown, I prefer to get around by using the underground pathways. There are also many shops and eateries which cater to the everyday and special needs of office workers.

reviews.title: Interesting maze
text: Use this path can help you to avoid the cold wind and rain.
This path is like a shopping street underground.

reviews.title: Convenient but...
text: I used the PATH system often but it can be hard to find your way. It’s best that you are not in a rush as you can get confused or lost easily until you know the way. It is great when the weather is bad outside. Not all access is signs posted. I found lots of exits and door that were not signed. The locals use it a lot and they know their way. It’s definitely worth using.

reviews.title: A BOON TO RESIDENTS NO DOUBT
text: The PATH is apparently more than 20 miles of underground pedestrian walkways in downtown Toronto. It connects restaurants and cafes, shops, hotels, entertainment outlets, and has transit links as well. Given the constant city crowds and the seasonal weather, it must be a real boon to the city residents. My wife and I strolled round one afternoon when stopping off in Toronto but, in truth, it's not my cup of tea. One can get too much retail therapy!

reviews.title: Confusing
text: Very interesting but utterly confusing for a traveller spending a day or so in the city.  Needs a better method for understanding how to navigate and more maps.

reviews.title: Very convenient
text: Great way to get around without worrying above the traffic. Also nice to use when it’s raining. We used the path to get from the CN tower to Union Station.

reviews.title: Way too confusing!!
text: Due to us traveling to Toronto during Labor Day weekend most of the stores inside the PATH were closed.  Which was odd to me, but we were told that it's mainly open during the day when business people are going to and from work.  How anyone can figure out this underground system I have no idea.  We were even asking locals how to get from point A to point B and they weren't 100% sure.  Could be a great concept especially in bad weather, but they need to make the directions much more clear.

reviews.title: EXCELLENT CONNECTION OF SHOPPING, RESTAURANTS, AND HOTEL
text: We stayed at the Sheraton Centre which is connected to the Path. The Path is very convenient for shopping and dining. Follwing it is tricky at times. We tried walking from the hotel to the Scotiabank Arena. It became very confusing around Union Station. We had to enter the street and ask for directions. Otherwise, it is very convenient.

reviews.title: Not a friend to the busy
text: Unless you know the PATH section you are in. You will get lost. Some areas are easier to navigate than others. If lost wander around find your way up you need fewer signs in the overground grid system.

The big stores that completely encapsulate the PATH have no signs and intend you to get lost. Though I have to admit if I'm lost I'm irritated and not motivated to buy anything, but must work for someone.

reviews.title: Excellent
text: Lots of shops, services and restaurants. Easily navigable and connections to transit, hotels, etc. There is also excellent maps, signage as well as a very useful third party navigation map.
If it is hot and muggy, raining or snowy and cold - it is great alternative.
However, you fight the crowds in morning and afternoon rush hours and the restaurants get crowded at lunch.

reviews.title: Fantastic
text: The PATH is over 20 miles of underground pedestrian walkways in downtown Toronto that connect restaurants,shopping,hotels,entertainment and transit hubs. The first underground section was built in 1900 by T Eaton to connect his department store to an annex store. Go to the Ontario Visitors Centre in Union Station and get a map of the PATH walkway and be amazed at where you can go without going outside in bad weather.

reviews.title: Godsend in winter, fun otherwise
text: The Path is Toronto’s underground city. As the winters can be extreme (to say the least) its a fantastic way of getting around downtown without having to brave the elements. It’s full of (mainly) small shops, convenience shops and eating places and stretches for miles under the Downtown area, with many entrances and exits. It’s also fun to do in the summer time.

reviews.title: Google Maps for the Path
text: Google Maps show the entire Path system if you zoom in just above street level. The Path routes are shown in green lines.

reviews.title: Was there in February before the lock down of the city
text: Was there in Feb before the lock down of the city. I was at the MUJI and Rexall Drug Store at the PATH.

reviews.title: Awesome Path
text: The path is the best way to get to places in the Financial District and keep warm during the winter months.  You can go from Union Station to Toronto City Hall, get closer to St. Lawrence Market, and go to many of the office buildings.  You can find great places to eat, have coffee, and buy almost everything you might need.  Exploring the path was fun and a sense of direction is helpful to get to the right place.  If you are not familiar with the city, getting a map of the path at Union Station would be helpful. There are also interactive maps at various places on the path.
I loved the experience of navigating the path and having a warm cup of coffee.

reviews.title: An important way to get around on foot in downtown Toronto - but could be signed better
text: As travellers, we like walkable cities, and Toronto is very much so. Integral for being a year-round place to walk around in is the vast PATH system - apparently 30 km's of walkways, most underground but some above. There are countless shops and restaurants, and most of the downtown attractions are linked to it somehow. Our only remark would be that while is signed, there are many 'dead spots' where more signage is needed, and visitors like us could go astray.

reviews.title: Wish is was longer
text: this is always great to visit when in the city when its cold and miserable out. there are so many options to eat and drink as well as shop. the best part is you can get to other locations without lugging your coat around

reviews.title: Underground city downtown Toronto
text: This underground of maze of shops, restaurants, businesses etc is like a warm, magical city under the cold and frozen city above ground.  My husband and I visited various sections of the path and it was quite enjoyable. You can spend hours exploring the path, and it’s a warm alternative to walking above ground in the cold!

reviews.title: Awful to navigate if you're a tourist!!
text: An array of shops. Transport, offices and subways.
Not very well signposted, you'll see a sign of where you want to be, head in that direction then the signage stops!!
Luckily the people are great and they always asking what you're looking for and point you in the right direction. Without them we'd probably still be wondering around now!!!
Personally we preferred the streets, far easier to navigate!!

reviews.title: Wish It Was Easier to Navigate
text: I've tried to use the Path system many times, with varying success.  It's very tricky to figure out where to go.  There is an app to use, but it doesn't give you step by step directions.  The premise is great, but I usually visit on the weekend, when none of the shops are open.  Wish this was executed better.

reviews.title: The Way to Go!
text: We visited Toronto in December to see a concert. It was raining and cold for three of the four days we spent there. We, therefore, found The Path very convenient and warm. It gets busy during business hours, especially at lunchtime. There is good shopping and many fast food restaurants along the way. There are several entrances and exits for each section, which bring you up to ground level. For the downtown core, you can certainly walk without wearing a jacket, provided you can enter from your hotel (not possible from all hotels). There are well-marked signs to help you maneuver your way through the labyrinth of walkwars. Too bad the entire city is not connected by this convenient system.

reviews.title: Challenging Exploration!
text: We explored the PATH system in early December when the weather outside was quite cold and drizzly. We found it connected directly to our hotel (Le Germain Hotel Toronto Maple Leaf Square) through a rear entrance. It led to Union Station and the Arena. It was quite challenging.

We were warned that you can easily get lost and we found out why. The signage is not always clearly placed and sometimes we had to back track to find our route again. This is a great system for travel within the city during bad weather, but it obviously takes getting used to.

reviews.title: Subterranean services and shopping galore
text: On a rainy or windy day, the PATH is a good and safe option. It’s accessible by subway, streetcars and GO train. To/from Union station, you can cross into the subway underground through doors to the PATH that passes along eating areas and shops. It’s nothing like Sainte-Catherine Montreal or Seoul’s above-/below-ground mecca around Myeongdong or Gangnam; but York’s Fairmont Hotel also offers underground access to the PATH with storefronts (beside Hockey Hall of Fame on Front Street). Hairdressing/barber, services and cafes dot the subterranean landscape that meanders North—towards Queen Street, smack between Bay Street and University Avenue. For example, nearby the Hudson’s Bay, clients preregister for PhysioPlus (Pineapple) Health group for therapy, acupuncturist and more. You would first pop out at Nathan Phillips Square beside the municipal underground car/charging lot. They’re the stairs leading to the “new” City Hall (a.k.a. Superman buildings), where free Saturday-Sunday events are held seasonally, beside Old City Hall or the stone courthouse—adjacent to Eaton’s Centre. There, you can also find many more shops, across Yonge street from Dundas Square movie theatre (used mornings as a lecture hall by Toronto Metropolitan University students). Renovations are being completed along the PATH, just in time for their wintry escape from Toronto’s bustle and streetcar traffic! Timing it just right, you can emerge from the trains and do all your window shopping…then even catch a theatrical performance or musical/show at Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts. There are plenty of dining options, besides Ruth Chris’ Steakhouse, next to Sheraton hotel’s secret courtyard-garden on Queen: facing Shangri-la (for afternoon tea if Fairmont is fully booked). If you’re adverse to cold weather…practically never exposing your face to the elements, this could be the PATH for you. Strolling underground, downtown, how could anyone go wrong in a city like Toronto?!

reviews.title: Underground shelter
text: The path offers great sheltering during the cold and snowy winter. I was able to avoid getting wet and cold by navigating the city via the path.

reviews.title: Very convenient getting from hotel to train to stores.
text: Very convenient getting from hotel to train to stores.   Lots of places to eat. Saves you from the outdoor elements.  Many options

reviews.title: Interesting Concept, Difficult Labyrinth
text: After three failed attempts to get to various locations around the city using the PATH, we finally made a successful trip to find dinner on our last night. I’m not sure what could be done to make it more user friendly but it was really confusing for us.

reviews.title: Very convenient way to get around
text: We recently used the Path during our 3 day stay in Toronto.  It was so much appreciated, as the weather was rainy and cold for most of our stay.  It was amazing to see what is offered.  In addition to the shops and restaurants, there had barbershops, dental offices, drugstores, etc.  We did think the signs could have been clearer in some areas and we had to ask someone a couple times for directions to where we were going but overall this is a great option, especially if you want to stay warm and dry.

reviews.title: Interesting walk
text: Exploring this underground path is a good way to escape from the snow and rain. There are also many shops down there. But please note the path is closed on weekends.

reviews.title: Good to escape the weather
text: Its a great idea if frustrating that you are carefully following the signs which then disappear. We started at the southmost point but lost all signs at the bus station. Even though we had a map. Ho hum.

reviews.title: Since underground pathways and shops
text: The pathways are a convenient way of getting away from the summer heat and winter weather. There are a nice mix of restaurants, food courts and a multitude of shops.

reviews.title: excellent place
text: excellent place to shop or take a stroll. under the main city of Toronto anyone can visit it whether its cold or hot outside.

reviews.title: Only in winter I think.
text: I only used to use underground city (PATH) in the dead of winter when the brutal cold was coming in off the water and while it’s more extensive now there is no reason to use it on a nice day. There are shops but not really worth the time to explore. I only understand it’s appeal when it’s cold.
